awd_titl_txt: III: Small: Algorithms and Practical Applications for Team Formation and Change
awd_abstract_narration:
For decades, researchers in sociology, psychology, organizational behavior, and other social sciences have been conducting quantitative data-analysis studies in order to understand and model how individuals form teams and how different factors (like diversity or homogeneity) affect team performance. Recently, the proliferation of online platforms for education, outsourcing, collaborative learning, software development and problem solving has also motivated computer scientists to work on the development of algorithms for team formation. This work closes the loop between the theory and practice of team-formation research. This is done by integrating social-science findings in the development of new computational problems and the design of new algorithms for team engineering, which is a term used to encompass the formation of teams and the modification of existing teams. Moreover, this work develops the necessary computational concepts as well as the software that enables the application of the team-recommendation algorithms to a variety of educational scenarios including hackathons, student entrepreneurship teams, as well as team formation in curricular and extracurricular project-based learning opportunities.

The research will have strong algorithmic, experimental and engineering components and will consist of the following research thrusts. Motivated by research in social sciences, in the first thrust the project will develop computational concepts enabling the formation of teams with low faultline potential. In the second thrust the project will focus on algorithms that modify existing teams in order to improve their functionality; in this thrust concepts that exist in social science research will again be used, viewed through computational lenses. In the final thrust the project will also consider the online team engineering problem where teams are formed on demand and consist both of core members and non-members that are temporarily hired in order to help with a particular task; in this scenario, the focus will be on algorithmic questions related to cost-optimizing strategies. In addition to these problems, the project will also consider problems arising in educational settings (e.g., hackathons, student entrepreneurship teams) and the development of a software platform to implement team-formation algorithms in such practical settings.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
In this project, we explored computational problems related to team formation and team engineering.  We also worked with Boston University (BU) Spark – an Innovation and experiental learning lab at BU – in order to form teams of students in different settings ranging from hackathons to large project-based classes.

 

Intellectual Merit: Motivated by work in social sciences as well as application domains such as education and human-resource management, we developed new concepts of team formation. We translated these concepts into their corresponding computational problems that aim to find (1) teams that consist of members that have high respect for each other, (2) teams that have low faultline potential (3) teams that work well for long periods of time, as well as (4) teams that balance project skill coverage and cost or alternatively project skill coverage and expert workload.  Moreover, we considered the online version of team formation where the team is created in an online fashion optimizing a hidden (unknown) objective.  For all these problems we developed new algorithmic solutions that are efficient and effective in theory and in practice.  For many of these algorithms we have theoretical results that bound their worst-case performance in terms of the problem objective. We also performed extensive experimental evaluation of these algorithms using real-world datasets from different application domains. The experimental results verified that our algorithms perform well in terms of finding teams that satisfy our objective.  We also investigated how the teams found have other important characteristics – even when those were not part of the explicit objective function.  Although our work is motivated by the team-formation setting, in certain cases the methodology we have developed goes beyond team formation application and it relates to core computational and machine-learning problems – for example, submodular function optimization or dense subgraph discovery.

 

Broader Impact: During this project we maintained a close relationship with BU Spark, and we made sure that we contribute to team-formation problems that arise in educational settings. This collaboration allowed us to apply team formation algorithms to hackathon participants and, in this way, contribute to improving the experience of the participants by recommending candidate collaborators to them before the day of the hackathon. This helped significantly participants from under-represented groups that signed up for hackathons without necessarily having a pre-defined team.  We also worked with BU spark in order to automate the process of forming teams of students to work on projects, in large project-based classes at BU. Our method took into consideration students’ preferences both for projects and collaborators and, consequently, improved the student happiness with their assignment. At the same time, it also improved the course administrators’ work, as before our involvement they were making such assignments manually for hundreds of students.

 

There were mainly four (one female) PhD students that were (partially) funded by this project. Two of them have graduated and found jobs as research scientists in companies such as Apple and Etsy. Three undergraduate students were also involved in research on topics related to this project. Two of them are already in graduate school (one at BU and another one at Yale), while the third one is currently applying for graduate school admission.

 

Finally, our conceptual algorithmic results have been published in major data mining and machine learning conferences and were disseminated through talks in universities and other research organizations.
